text: I'm Kate Galbraith with the New York
Times again it's fall and Halloween is
approaching so I thought I might try to
find some pumpkins to make a decorative
jack-o'-lantern and keep the seeds to
roast them and have a tasty treat all in
a green way of course so I went down to
my local food co-op and found Joe Holt
who is passionate about pumpkin Joe if I
wanted to find a cheap green ideally
organic pumpkin would some of these fit
the bill well these are actually grown
by an organic farmer but in the last
this year and last year she's converting
over some land that was used for
conventional agriculture so she can't
call it organic yet so I sign says
minimally treated you know so it sounds
pretty green to me yeah it's very green
and the price is that the coop will
probably keep some green in my pocket
this was about a 10 pound pumpkin for
five dollars in addition to the fairly
cheap minimally treated pumpkins the
coop had fully organic pumpkins for a
dollar seven a pound that's cheaper than
my local Whole Foods carving a pumpkin
can be pretty messy work do I use a
newspaper down on the counter it's a
good way to reuse the paper oh I see
some seeds I got the seeds out wash them
off and mix them with a bit of oil and
salt before spreading them on a cookie
sheet now they're going into the oven
which I just heated it 350 degrees while
the seeds are cooking I decided to try
carving my pumpkin with my
jack-o'-lantern looking pretty good it
was time to check on the seeds see how
they did they're not as brown as they're
supposed to be I think but I'm kind of
hungry and they're still pretty tasty
happy organic Halloween
